newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Big oil exchanges plan 24-hour global market.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Big oil exchanges plan 24-hour global market.

text.p: The world's two leading oil exchanges are studying ways to develop a global 24-hour energy market with a view to boosting trading volumes while promising big cost savings for their members and the oil industry.

Close cooperation between rivals the International Petroleum Exchange (IPE) in London and the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) would almost certainly stifle an infant oil futures market in Singapore.

"We are planning to set up a common electronic trading system where you can trade energy products whether in the U.S. or in London on one common platform which you can access on a 24-hour basis," said the IPE's head of product development Richard Ward.
"We are trying to set up a global energy market."

Ward was speaking after NYMEX and the IPE issued a joint statement confirming detailed discussions would start soon on ways of developing a common out-of-hours trading system, among other areas of cooperation.

The talks, due to bear fruit by late summer, would also explore joint systems development, marketing and cross-margining -- reducing the cash traders have to pay up front for spread trades between the exchanges' contracts.
A full-scale merger was not on the cards, he said.
"The overall objective behind this cooperation is to grow both exchanges volumes," Ward said.
"We have entered into this with the belief that there are real benefits to be accrued for the members and therefore for the customers."
Both exchanges offer oil producers, traders and refiners the oppportunity to hedge price risk on crude oil and refined products such as heating oil and gasoline.
IPE daily trading volumes on Brent during the last 12 months have averaged over 40,000 lots, equivalent to 40 million barrels of crude or over half of world demand.
North Sea Brent Blend crude is widely traded on the international spot market and therefore regarded as the best benchmark for world prices.
A link-up with NYMEX would almost certainly boost IPE volumes.

But at the Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX), which carries a Brent contract under a five-year pact with the London exchange, brokers see see a threat to Asia's only oil futures market.
"It all sounds pretty ominous," said a senior SIMEX broker.
And SIMEX could obstruct the IPE's ambitions by refusing to clear its link with NYMEX.
SIMEX said on Thursday its agreement with the IPE gaive it trading rights on Brent during Singapore hours.
The IPE's Ward rejected suggestions the IPE was aiming to drop its Asian partner.

"We want the SIMEX agreement to succeed... Clearly we need to have the agreement of all the interested parties to be able to progress this -- we do not want to end up with an adversarial relationship with any exchange," Ward said.
